You might also consider looking at ways to create a Project without a
database.  As J.B Rainsberger stated, your Experiment tests do not
care much about creating a project - they just want one.

The same is true then for most of our Project tests as well.  You can
one (or a few) test to make sure that writing to the DB works - but
subsequent tests (that again care little about the creation of a
Project but rather just want a Project) can use a Project that was not
database driven.

There are several advantages to following the above style including 

1) Speed of test execution (non-database driven tests are usually
faster than database tests),

2) Complexity of test setup (in its current state - each test that
requires a Project also requires the database and managing that is
more complex then simply using an in-memory Project),

3) Increased test de-coupling (if the database goes down, or is
improperly configured, then all your Project tests will fail - instead
of those that more concretely point to a database issue)

To be fair, there are some disadvantages as well.

1) Fewer tests exercise a real Project (aka database driven) - but we
are talking about unit tests so in most circles this is expected (you
can still use a database driven Project for integration tests)

2) Code refactoring to support DB driven and non-db driven Projects. 
You could consider Mock-objects, abstracting the persistence layer (to
now include an In-Memory as well as database implementation) as well
as just re-thinking how objects interact with one another (is the
foreign key constraint an Experiment issue, or a database one?)

andrew f



On Fri, 03 Sep 2004 17:27:21 -0500, J. B. Rainsberger
<jbrains@...> wrote:
> sebashkw wrote:
> 
> > Say I have a Project class and Experiment class that I need to test using
> > Junit. They are simple codes that writes into the database. The rule is a
> > Project must be added before a Experiment can be added. This is
> > because Experiment has a foreign key that points to Project.
> 
> OK. Project [1]-->[*] Experiment.
> 
> > In my ProjectTest I have a testCreateProject test. But in my
> > ExperimentTest where I have my testCreateExperiment test, I need to
> > create a project before it will be successful.
> >
> > Whats the practice for this? Do I put the createProject inside my
> > testCreateExperiment method? Then I will be actually testing two different
> > class (Project and Experiment) in a single method
> > (testCreateExperiment)..
> 
> I don't agree with this last statement.
> 
> In what state does your environment need to be to test creating an
> experiment? It appears that there must be a project in the database with
> a known project primary key first. In that case, put one there -- this
> is what setUp() is for. In TestExperiment.setUp(), then, invoke
> createProject().
> 
> Rather than /testing/ createProject(), you are /using/ createProject()
> -- assuming that it works -- to test createExperiment(). I'm not sure
> that that's wise, but that's another subject, covered in depth in _JUnit
> Recipes_.
> 
> > If anyone is going to suggest control the order of executing the test (i.e.
> > run ProjectTest before ExperimentTest), note that I need the return value
> > from testCreateProject in testCreateExperiment.
> 
> That's fine -- store that value in a field of TestExperiment and let
> testCreateExperiment() use that field.
